newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish yields rise on weak crown.
newsitem.headline: Swedish yields rise on weak crown.

text.p: Swedish debt yields opened lower but ended higher on Tuesday on a weakening crown and higher international yields.
"These are sensitive levels. Some countries in Europe are at a record low at the moment," one dealer said.
"The yields rose on weaker international markets and a weakening crown against the mark."
Six month T-bill rates rose six basis points to 4.01 percent. The ten year bond yield rose seven to 6.64 percent.
One dealer said he was amazed yields opened down in the morning seeing the weakness of the crown.
The crown weakened on a weaker Italian lira as well as on general concerns about EMU, dealers said.

"The dollar came down under the 1.70-level against the mark which made the crown weaker against the mark. The Riksbank decision to keep its repo rate unchanged at 4.10 percent might have pushed the crown down," one dealer said.
The crown weakened to 4.3910 crowns to the mark versus 4.3645 crowns late on Monday.
The Riksbank presented December current account data which was below expectations at a surplus of 0.9 billion crowns against expectations of 2.1 billion.
Foreign interest payments were said to have impacted on the surplus.
Dealers said the focus for the market on Wednesday would be the U.S. Consumer Price Index and trade balance.
"The trade balance will be interesting because it will show the direction of the dollar," one dealer said.
